projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
PRESENT,
The Kings MoÅ¿t Excellent MajeÅ¿ty.
His Royal HighneÅ¿s the Duke of York.
His HighneÅ¿s Prince Rupert.
Lord ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury.
Duke of Buckingham.
Duke of Ormond.
Earl of OÅ¿Å¿ery.
Lord Chamberlain.
Earl of Bridgewater.
Earl of Sandvvich.
Earl of AngleÅ¿ey.
Earl of CarliÅ¿le.
Earl of Craven.
Earl of Lauderdale.
Lord Nevvport.
Lord AÅ¿hley.
Mr. TreaÅ¿urer.
Mr. Vice-Chamberlain.
Mr. Secretary Trevor.
MaÅ¿ter of the Ordnance.
Mr. Mountague.

HIs MajeÅ¿ty, having this day Ordered the Lords, and others of His Privy Council to attend him in Council, is pleaÅ¿ed to declare, That Å¿eeing all the Princes, and States, His Neighbours, were making great preparations for Warr, both by Sea and Land, His MajeÅ¿ty, for the Å¿afety of his Government
and People, lookt upon HimÅ¿elf as obliged to make Å¿uch Preparations as might be proportionable for the Protection both of the one and the other; And to that end he has already given Orders for the fitting and preparing a very conÅ¿iderable Fleet, to be ready againÅ¿t the Spring.

By this inevitable neceÅ¿Å¿ity, His MajeÅ¿ty conÅ¿idering the great Charges that muÅ¿t attend Å¿uch Preparations, and after His Å¿erious debates and beÅ¿t conÅ¿iderations, not finding any poÅ¿sibility to defray Å¿uch unuÅ¿ual Expences by the uÅ¿ual wayes and means of borrowing Moneys, by reaÅ¿on His Revenues were Å¿o anticipated and engaged, He was neceÅ¿sitated (contrary to His own inclinations) upon theÅ¿e emergencies, and for the Publick Safety, at the preÅ¿ent, to cauÅ¿e a Stop to be made of the payment of any Moneys, now being, or to be brought into His Exchequer, for the Å¿pace of one whole Year, ending the laÅ¿t day of December next, unto any perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever, by vertue of any Warrant, Securities, or Orders, whether RegiÅ¿tred or not RegiÅ¿tred therein, and payable within that time; Excepting onely Å¿uch payments as Å¿hall grow due upon Orders on the SubÅ¿idy, according to the Act of Parliament, and Orders and Securities upon the Fee-Farm Rents, both which are to be proceeded upon as if this Stop had never been made.

And that His MajeÅ¿ties PleaÅ¿ure and Declaration may be Å¿peedily and effectually put in Execution, His MajeÅ¿ty doth Order, and doth hereby require and command Sir Heneage Finch Knight and Baronet, His Attorney General, forthwith to prepare a Bill for His Royal Signature, and Å¿o to paÅ¿s
the Great Seal, thereby requiring and commanding the Lords CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of His TreaÅ¿ury, immediately to order and direct all and every the Officers of His MajeÅ¿ties Exchequer, to Post-pone all Warrants and Orders, whether RegiÅ¿tred or not RegiÅ¿tred, and other Securities and Payments whatÅ¿oever, (except as before excepted) until the laÅ¿t day of December next.

And in the mean time, the Lords CommiÅ¿sioners of His TreaÅ¿ury to be Required and Authorized, to cauÅ¿e payment to be made of the IntereÅ¿t that is or Å¿hall grow due, at the rate of Six pounds per Cent. unto every perÅ¿on that Å¿hall have Money due to him or them upon Å¿uch Warrants, Orders, or Securities, Å¿o PoÅ¿t-pon'd and deferr'd; and that the payment of Å¿uch IntereÅ¿t may be juÅ¿tly made, the Lords CommiÅ¿sioners of His TreaÅ¿ury are to be Authorized and Required, to cauÅ¿e the Debt of every particular perÅ¿on, and the Å¿aid IntereÅ¿t thereof, to be truly Å¿tated.

And the Lords of His MajeÅ¿ties TreaÅ¿ury are farther to be Ordered and Required, to employ and diÅ¿poÅ¿e of all the Å¿aid Moneys, Å¿o Å¿topp'd and detained, for the preparing, Å¿etting forth, and payment of His MajeÅ¿ties Fleet, and other Publick Services, in order to the preÅ¿ervation and Å¿afety of His MajeÅ¿ties Government, and defence of His People, as His MajeÅ¿ty Å¿hall from time to time Order and Direct.

And His MajeÅ¿ty, as far as in him lies, to take away all apprehenÅ¿ions or terrour, that might poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s any of His Subjects Å¿pirits, doth declare, That no perÅ¿on whatÅ¿oever Å¿hall be defrauded of any thing that is juÅ¿tly due to him, nor Å¿hall this reÅ¿traint, which His MajeÅ¿ty has been compelled
(not being able for the preÅ¿ent to find any other expedient) to lay upon Å¿uch Monies, as are or Å¿hall be paid into His Exchequer, continue longer then the aforeÅ¿aid laÅ¿t day of December: and that then no new Warrants, Orders or Securities Å¿hall intervene, to break the courÅ¿e of Å¿uch Payments.

And His MajeÅ¿ty is graciouÅ¿ly pleaÅ¿ed farther to declare, That nothing could have urged His MajeÅ¿ty to an Act of this Nature, but Å¿uch a conjuncture of Affairs, when all the Neighbouring Princes and States were making Å¿uch Threatning preparations, that His government could not be Å¿afe without appearing in the Å¿ame poÅ¿ture.
In the SAVOY, Printed by the AÅ¿signs of John Bill, and ChriÅ¿topher Barker, Printers to the Kings moÅ¿t Excellent MajeÅ¿ty, 1671/2
